While Valentineâ€™s Day does have history behind it, many people feel the day has become more about consumerism and less about relationships and love. 
According to a 2015 survey by digital coupons website RetailMeNot.ca, 78 per cent of Canadians feel Valentineâ€™s Day is an overrated occasion.

â€œI usually hear single people referring to Valentineâ€™s Day as annoying more than couples,â€ she says. â€œBut I think itâ€™s as popular for couples. People want to feel special so they do want to celebrate it still.â€ Why the haters? 
Lovers are about to drop some serious cash in the days leading up to Feb. 14. 
Canadians in particular spend an average of $164 on Valentineâ€™s Day, RetailMeNot.com says. 
In terms of gifts, this is what Canadians are buying and the average price theyâ€™re paying: Jewelry: $190 Tickets to a show: $76 Lingerie: $61 Flowers $40 Candy or chocolate $18 
And the pressure is on, especially for men ( 80 per cent of Canadians tell RetailMeNot.com that they agree men are more pressured on Valentineâ€™s Day). In fact, men tend to spend an average of $219 just to make their partners happy.

â€œThere is nothing wrong with going out of your way for your partner in terms of gifts, favours, planning or sex,â€ she says. â€œIf Valentineâ€™s Day offers the perfect excuse or reminder for you to do so, then I believe it serves an important purpose. â€œI believe that small gestures spread out over the course of your relationship are more important than grand gestures mandated by a commercially based holiday,â€ Oâ€™Reilly says. â€œI also worry that the pressure to be romantic and/or sexual on a very specific day causes more distress than pleasure for some couples.â€

â€œI think we need that reminder to love a little harder on a certain day,â€ she says. â€œWe live in a world that is so busy that I think we need a day to stop, take a breath and focus on the connection with our partner. If we didnâ€™t have this day then Iâ€™d worry that people wouldnâ€™t take that time.â€

â€œJust be really nurturing to yourself,â€ she says. â€œBe your own Valentine and do something special for yourself. Cook that dinner, treat yourself to that expensive wine, listen to your favourite music. Sometimes you deserve some self love.â€ All the single ladies â€“ and men 
The number of single people in Canada continues to surpass the number of married couples, Statistics Canada reports. 
In 2016, there were over 14.3 million singletons in the country (about 7.6 million of which were men and 6.7 million women. Now, as to how many of them are in a serious dating relationship is unknown. 
â€œ[Valentineâ€™s Day] certainly doesnâ€™t appeal to single and singles are a fast growing segment of our population,â€ Oâ€™Reilly says. â€œWeâ€™re delaying cohabitation and marriage.â€

â€œI call [Valentineâ€™s Day] â€˜Love Day,â€™â€ says McCance. â€œWhat if you were just to celebrate relationships in general? It could be your romantic relationship, but it could also be the relationships you have with your family and friends. Celebrate the love. I think if we remove that romantic pressure then itâ€™s just celebrating this wonderful thing called love.â€ 
But if the day really bothers you, both McCance and Oâ€™Reilly offer some tips on how to lift your spirits up. 
One way to do that is to involve your friends. 
â€œOne thing I used to do was to invite my single girlfriends over and weâ€™d order in and Iâ€™d have little chocolates and gifts for them,â€ McCance says. â€œIt was celebrating our friendships and even our relationship statues. I just felt so much joy in celebrating them.â€
